just like so many of the other Amazon web services every time one comes along that really fits our need like Cloud

jasse thank you it is great to be here with you and we really appreciate you're
taking a full day out of your time to learn more about AWS I hope you find the day useful we have been working on AWS for
10 10 years actually when we first came up with the idea and we've had services in the market now for seven years and
even though we've built quite a bit we really think of this business and this platform that we've built as seven years
young and that's CU we have so much we're bringing to you just this year and in the coming years so keep the requests
coming keep the feedback coming and we're going to keep delivering quickly for you but in the interim we've built a
pretty substantial technology infrastructure platform that's really fully featured it's got a number of
compute Services a number of storage Services a number of database Services a
Content distribution Network a number of application Services a number of
management tools and abstractions to make it easier to use our platform and then a whole bunch of people Services we
have Professional Services now we have AWS premium developer support and then
we have AWS training and our newest people service which we announced today with a press release the new AWS
certification program I would say that outside of our
operational performance and security over the seven years that we've been doing this business probably the thing
we're collectively most proud of is the pace at which we've been able to innovate and iterate on behalf of our
customers and you can see in 2007 about a year after we got started we released
nine significant services and features in 2008 that number was 24 in 2009 it
doubled to 48 in 2010 it was over 60 in 11 it was over 80 last year in
2012 we released nearly 160 significant features and services and that pace is
continuing to increase as time progresses this year alone in the first four months of
2013 we've delivered over 70 significant services and features for you guys which
is great news for customers because as most of you know our road map in AWS is
largely prioritized based on what you tell us matters and so that means you get more more quickly and it means you
can move more of your workloads over and save time and money in the process we have a very broad Geographic
footprint at this point all over the world and the way to think about the terminology in AWS is a region is a
place somewhere in the world where we have physical infrastructure so each region has multiple data centers or what
we call availability zones and we have nine regions at this point we have one
on the east coast of the United States two on the west coast of the United States one in Europe one in Singapore
one in Tokyo One in Sydney Australia one in South America and Brazil and then we
have a government only region in the US that we call govcloud that has itar
compliance which um effectively means that only US citizens can work on the the workloads there and that is really
important for a number of public sector workloads that have that requirement so we have nine regions all over the world
25 availability zones and 39 points of presence or Edge locations for our
content distribution Network Amazon cloudfront just to give you a few points
of scale for the platform so our storage service which is Amazon simp Le storage
service Amazon S3 stores over 2 trillion objects and it took us about 6 years to
accumulate the first trillion objects and only a year to accumulate the second trillion and then just to give you an
idea at the scope at which the service operates we do over 1.1 million requests
per second it's very large scope in these Services we have a service called Amazon
elastic map produce which is really a dupe implementation on top of Amazon ec2
our compute service and we've done 5.5 million clusters in the last couple
years alone and then this is a really interesting data point if you if you
look at how much new server capacity that AWS is delivering every day it
would have handled all of Amazon globally back in 2003 when we were a
$5.2 billion business with 7 ,800 employees so every single day now we're
adding enough new servers to have handled all of Amazon globally when we are a $5 billion business with nearly
8,000 employees that's a lot of data centers and a lot of servers that we're building every
day we have a very diverse and large customer base we have hundreds of thousands of customers in over 190
countries and they range from some of the most widely consumed internet
properties like Pinterest and Spotify and Instagram and Airbnb and Dropbox to
some of the largest Enterprises in the world like Netflix and shell and Samsung
and Bristol Meers squib and Hitachi and tashiba to the public sector where we
have over 500 government agencies worldwide wide using AWS and over 2,000
academic institutions using AWS so very diverse customer
base and when we started AWS when we were conceiving of it and thinking about
what to build we had massive debate internally about where we should build
the services how much functionality we should build in how many of the decisions we should make for our
developers and at the end of the day what we decided was that we wanted to build very flexible primitive building
blocks that's why when you look at the AWS logo and you always see those blocks that connotes these building building
blocks that were giving our developers to stitch together however they see fit and we also very consciously decided
that we were not going to be paternal we weren't going to make decisions for our developers and part of what that really
enabled was enabled our customers to stitch together our services however
they saw fit to build whatever applications they could imagine or needed and that's why you see literally
every imaginable use case on top of AWS from Dev test to all kinds of internal
and external website applications to Media distribution to high performance
Computing and batch analytics to archival and Disaster Recovery to
Mission critical applications literally every imaginable application now is running on top of
AWS one of the questions that we get asked a lot um maybe a lot more so in
the beginning um but it's always an important question to customers is is is
the platform secure enough and that is has got to be priority number one for every company it's certainly priority
number one for AWS and so we use all the same strategies and tactics of technology
companies the last 30 years we have very strict Access Control to our data
centers we do a lot of uh uh work to make sure that none of the packets over
the network are being intercepted in any fashion we're very careful to wipe our Hardware clean when customers give up
that hardware and aren't using it anymore but we've also added quite a few features over the last several years and
continue to do so that allow customers to have even more security capabilities
on top of the platform and you see that with what we've done with identity and access management and very uh granular
user management features um you see it with multifactor authentication that we provide our customers the opportunity to
use you see it with offering customers dedicated instances that they somehow want to be the only ones running on a
particular box you see it with all kinds of encryption of our persistent stores and in our networking
layer a lot of our customers said okay as I inspect what you're doing on a
security basis I'm pretty impressed but my company is going to insist that there are certain certifications and
accreditations that you guys have in order to feel comfortable moving workloads to your platform and that's
why over the last several years we have added a whole host of certifications that our customers asked us for ranging
from sock to PCI compliance to ISO
2701 to being uh able to run Hippa workloads in our our Cloud to the motion
picture uh Association of America that where we had a lot of media customers
and film customers that wanted to be able to store comfortably their Assets in our Cloud we got that certification
to a number of public sector certifications like fsma low fsma moderate itar fips very very broad set
of certifications that's made it easier for our customers to do what they want to do in our
Cloud we have had for a long time I'd say at Amazon in general and in AWS in
specific here a very clear and consistent pricing philosophy there are a number of
companies uh and most of the Old Guard technology companies fit in this class
whose pricing philosophy really is to charge as much as they can and that is
by the way that's a successful strategy it's a high margin business strategy and
it's a totally reasonable business strategy it just happens not to be ours
and you can see that in what we do we work relentlessly to take cost out of
our own cost structure and then pass them back to you our customers in the form of lower prices and we we've done
that on 31 different occasions in the last several years in the absence of competitive pressure to do so and what
that really has done is it's it's given us this very interesting and useful virtuous circle where as we have more
AWS customers it leads to more AWS usage as we have more AWS usage we have to buy
more infrastructure as we buy more infrastructure it gives us economies of scale which lowers our infrastructure
costs which allows us to reduce our prices which spins that virtuous circle again and as it turns out you actually
can inject energy into this flywheel in various spots if you have a very vibrant
ecosystem if you have a broad Global footprint if you add a lot of features and services it drives more customers
and more usage and Spins that wheel and similarly on the infrastructure side if
you're able to invent and innovate in your infrastructure and we have a lot of IP that we're working on all the time it
allows us to lower our costs which allows us to lower our prices which again spins that wheel which is very
very useful for our customers we are so focused on reducing C uh cost for
customers that we invent features like AWS trusted advisor so trusted advisor
is a feature of our AWS support offering and what we do is we have technology
that automatically goes and checks for all kinds of different different levers that would help you be more secure or
more available or spend less on AWS and you can see that one of the things we do
is we check if you're running steady state workloads that are highly utilized but you're running them on demand at a
higher cost than it would be if you actually bought reserved instances where you can save about half of the cost of
running on demand or we'll look at when you have idle instances that you're not using or we'll look at when you have low
utilization for your footprint and what we'll do then is we will proactively send alerts and contact you and say you
should be spending less money on AWS now think about it how many technology
companies will call you up and say I think you should spend less money with me not too many but that's because AWS
and Amazon as a whole has a culture where the most important thing the thing that permeates everything we do is that
we start with customers and then everything evolves backwards from there and I've been in Amazon for uh roughly
16 years at this point I've worked on every business that we've been in and I can tell you that I have never met
customers in any of those businesses that want to pay more and so you should expect this from us this is not a
gimmick this is not something we're doing for Optics this is not something we're trying to do to get attention in
the Press on a short-term basis this is how we're built this is our DNA and you should continue to expect this from
AWS from the beginning we always believed that having a vibrant
growing successful ecosystem was very strategic AWS and we have partnered very
closely with isvs and with systems integrators from the Geto and you can
see it in how vibrant that ecosystem is on the systems integrator side we we
have literally thousands of systems integrators that help companies move their workloads and be more efficient on
AWS they range from Cap Gemini and COG and infosis and boo Allen and on the isv
side the technology partner side we have a very large vibrant ecosystem as well
and they they range from sap and Oracle and ezri and Aquia and mongodb and one
of the things that has further helped this isv ecosystem has been the AWS
Marketplace which we launched just about a year ago and this is a Marketplace that you can find on AWS where there are
third party solution that you can buy and you can even buy them in one click they're very easy to
deploy we have 25 product categories and almost 800 listings at this point and
that's growing very very aggressively each month and if you look just from
January 1st to this year you can see that our active customers are double from what they were before and the usage
per customer is growing by over 50% for per customer so a very useful vehicle
for our isv partners
another piece of the ecosystem that makes a big difference for customers is
our customer ecosystem when there's a big technology shift that's happening
like what's moving to the cloud if you have more fellow customers either in
your industry or that are geographically close to you that are using that
platform it's more comfortable and it's easier to move you also have more people to talk talk to about best practices the
forums at those company's we that cloud provider's websites are really vibrant
and active if you need to hire developers who is part of their skill set have AWS as a background and if you
look at how many job descriptions now have AWS skills as a requirement it's pretty astounding that's helpful but
what's also very important is that if you've got a large customer ecosystem it
drives the partner ecosystem some I was just talking about to really want to build their Solutions on top of that
platform and vice versa they're very they reinforce each other in a very important
way so why are so many customers moving to the cloud so
fast and there's a lot of noise about this point and there's a lot of companies that have tried to kind of
Commander this type of messaging for uh for their own purposes but I thought i'
give you perspective because we've been doing it the longest and we have very large business as the leader and I
thought I would share with you at least what our customers are telling us the first thing
is if you can trade Capital expense for variable expense for most businesses
that's a big business Advantage if you don't have to lay out all that Capital up front for data centers and for
servers before you know what you're working on is going to work and instead get to consume it only as you need it
that gives you a lot more flexibility so you get to trade Capital expense for variable expense and then
number two it turns out that we can provide you a lower variable expense than what most customers can do on their
own and that's because AWS has such large scale at this point that we're able to take those economies of scale
and pass them back to you in the form of lower prices and there are lots of customer examples we could site you for
square with their analytics platform has saved 50% an operating cost the
Commonwealth Bank of Australia has saved tens of millions of dollars just in the first dozen applications they've
deployed AWS and they're increasing that footprint on AWS Spiegel TV in Germany
was able to transcode 20,000 TV shows that they had wanted to do by the way for many years but just hadn't found the
resource to do it they were able to do it in a couple days for less than it would have cost for the electricity in
their own Data Center and in fact when when you look at an independent study that was done by IDC they found when
they did the 5-year tcco analysis that it's 70% lower to run on AWS than it is
to run on Prem so you get to trade Capital expense for variable expense it's a lower
variable expense than you can do on your own and then you don't have to be guessing at how much capacity you're
going to need so for most people that are working on something new that dotted Green Line represents you know an
estimate of what you think the capacity is going to be and it's hard to estimate that it's really hard to predict what's going to happen and that solid white
line is an example of an actual demand curve for that same project and what you can see is on the left side of that
graph you're sitting on all this wasted Capital which is frustrating and on the
right side of the graph you don't have enough capacity so you either have to provide a bad customer experience or
what most people do is they run around like a chicken with their head cut off and they do a short-term deal that has a
long-term commitment and it means that they overpay for it and they have to sit on that Peak even if they don't need it
long term the cloud changes all of that you don't have to guess anymore you just
consume resources as you need them and if you need to scale up you seamlessly scale up if it turns out you hit a peak
and you don't need to retain that capacity you don't have to eat it you get to give it back to us and stop paying for it that's a very different
model in the last 30 years the fourth thing that customers tell us and why they're moving to the
cloud and I would say with Enterprises over the last you know 18 months or so
this has become maybe the most compelling reason for them is that they actually can move much faster and get
more done for Less when we started AWS we talked to a number of companies
and we do this same study every three months or so we talk to developers a lot of companies and we say how long does it
take you to get a server if you want to put something in in tag or you want to test something or do something new and
the answer is we got back ranged from 6 weeks to 25 weeks that's maddening if
you're a developer that's just maddening and in fact what a lot of development teams do at that point is they give up
on doing anything new because why bother it's going to take so long to get that server anyway in the cloud the world is
very different you can actually spin up hundred even thousands of servers in minutes and it's all self-service you
can do it on your own without having to go through a million departments to make it happen and anybody that does a lot of
invention will tell you that arguably the two most important factors in doing invention is number one you have to be
able to try a lot of experiments and number two if those experiments don't work and if you're really pushing the
envelope a lot of your experiments should not work not having to live with the collateral damage of failed
experiments in the cloud if those experiments don't work you either just give them back to us and stop paying for
it or you just take those same servers and use them for your next set of experiments very different model and
here are just a few examples of that you can see News International they were able to reduce their deployment time
from two months to 3 days Lion's gate went from weeks to hours and being able to deploy you can see band page can
double their capacity in 20 seconds very very different model in fact again when IDC did an
independent study on this last year they found that the agility amounted to 5x
faster on AWS than what companies can do on Prem the fifth thing that people tell us
is it's a huge Advantage not to have to manage the undifferentiated heavy lifting yourself running data centers is
not impossible but to do it at scale and as you're growing it's hard it's hard to
do well you have to go contract with a a Colo provider or build your own data
center you got to negotiate Hardware you have to install the hardware you have to
manage heterogeneous Hardware you have to migrate Hardware you have to set up a
network you have to negotiate with a bandwidth provider you have to set all that up you have to uh operate all this
if there are any problems you're on the hook to operate it and so if you can take the skill SC resource in your
company which most technology departments most companies that do technology find that the scarce resource
are software development Engineers if you can take those software development engineers and instead of having them
focus on the infrastructure which is important but it hardly ever differentiates your business in any
meaningful way if you can have those software development Engineers working on things that truly differentiate your
business or Mission that's a big business advantage and that's what you can do in the class
and the sixth benefit we hear frequently from our customers is that they can be Global in minutes this is really
different from the way the world existed before first of all not only Enterprises but even startups today have Global and
users right from the get-go because of the internet and the way the world works and in the old days if you wanted to
actually have your applications live in infrastructure all over the world it was
really hard to do it was expensive it was hard to find somebody you trusted it was hard to deploy in those spots with
AWS you can deploy in regions nine regions all over the world in minutes
and in fact a good example of this recently is quantis Airlines in Australia they built a hotel booking
business called huru that actually books hotels along with all their flight plans and they have multiple Airlines they do
this with and they were able to deploy to a new region with two people in two
days that is a very very different model so to summarize these are the
benefits that we hear customers tell us really matter you get to trade Capital expense or variable expense it's a lower
variable expense than you can do on your own you don't have to guess on what capacity you need it's purely elastic
you actually get to move much more quickly get more done for less and less time you get to focus those scarce
resources which are your engineers on things to truly differentiate your business and you can have a global
footprint with a better customer experience because of lower latency in minutes if you need to that those are
very compelling benefits and to give you an idea of how that works in practice I
wanted to bring somebody up who is the lead engineer at a startup that went in just one year from founding to
developing an app that processed 100 million emails per day to an acquisition
all in the cloud my guest is Sean [Music]
bosai thank you Andy and thank you to adbs for having me up here today as Andy said I lead the engineering team for
mailbox and I'm here today to tell you a little bit about how mailbox came to be
and how we leveraged AWS to make it into what it is today so first I want to give
give you a little bit of History so a little over 2 years ago a few of us sat down in the living room of our
co-founder's house with a mission of helping the world helping people work better together and the first iteration
on that mission was Orchestra to-do and for those of you that don't know Orchestra to-do is a lightning fast
social social collaboration management system and we launched it a little over a year and a half ago and the reception
was overwhelmingly positive and our users loved it it but we came to realize
that it had one fundamental issue and that was that we couldn't get our users to stick with the product and so we
started grappling with this is this this issue and asking ourselves why we we found out that all the important things
for us day-to-day and all the important things for our users and the people we interacted with was still stuck in email
and so we took a step back we asked ourselves could we take this place that held all this important information and
could we reinvent this inbox where all these tasks already lived and we asked ourselves could a
small team of designers and Engineers tackle this daunting and previously Untouchable problem and so that launched
us on this iterative journey of prototyping and building and scrapping and building all of which eventually
became mailbox and after months and months of hard work we put together a video to show the world that we had been
working on and instead of trying to explain the product to you myself I'd like to just show that video to you

prests so we launched this video in December and we were hoping to get about
100,000 views as we ramp toward product launch but what ended up happening is we
got that in about 4 hours and from the early users we had on our on our product from the press the reception was just
overwhelmingly positive and it started to feel like we had the scent of product Market fit and we knew that what they
were reacting to was this amazing client engineering these fluid animations this beautiful UI this fresh take on the
inbox but we also knew that in order to power this experience we had to build a massively scaled backend that would
iterate on this 25-year-old iMat protocol and build it in a way that was
better design for a world on the go and so to hope you better understand um what
that meant for us let me break down mailbox for you a little bit so the cloud is an essential part of why
mailbox is so fast and seamless mailbox checks the mail on your behalf reformats
the messages and efficiently delivers them down to your client and for every email address that's added to our system
we have instantaneous load because we need to sync your data as fast as possible and then we have continuous
load throughout the day because whether you're in our product or not you're going to be interacting with your email
and we need to stay in sync with all of those data events you add to that that this is email it's business critical
can't go down it can't be slow has to always be fast and always be available
and that all adds up to quite a bit infrastructure and a really hard problem for a small
team so we knew that in order to scale up to meet this demand that we are seeing that we had to have a production
level uh backend system from the very first day and so we turned to AWS to
help us do that and we knew that we wanted to find as many limits and bottlenecks in our system before we
launched and long before they could ever negatively affect any of our users and so what we decided to do was spin up an
exact mirrored clone of our backend sitting next to our normal backend infrastructure and this included our SSD
databases our application servers the whole thing and instead of slamming our
own email accounts with hundreds of thousands to millions of data events to load test our own system we built an
IMAP server that we were able to sit right next to it and because this was on demand it was really quite powerful for
us it was both cost effective and very effective for our team to be able to find we found assumptions that were just
incorrect at larger scale we found bottlenecks that we just didn't anticipate and layers that we needed to
kind of rearchitecturing
growth as as users were added but we knew that no matter what we did we
weren't going to be able to build it perfectly from the very first day and so we knew that also that was what what was
most important for us was that the users that were already in the system had the best experience possible so we decided
to build this reservation system because we didn't want any new load being added to the system to negatively affect
anyone else who was already in and the reason this slide says rapid product development is because the story of our reservation
system is really a microcosm of our team how our team operates we identify a problem we prototype we iterate and we
execute in a very short amount of time and that's that was very true for our reservation system just a few weeks
before launch when we decided to implement this we had two engineers build the whole thing end to end in just
under a week and we turned AWS to help us power that we knew we needed a database that was reliable that would
meet that would uh handle all of the scale and demand of all these requests that would be coming in and one that we
didn't really want to manage because we needed to focus on scaling our core product we didn't expect this
reservation system to be around forever and RDS was an amazing asset for us in being able to execute this system
quickly but no matter what we did to prepare for scale with spinning up this mirrored system and throttling the load
of new users added there was nothing that really could have truly prepared us for what it was like to launch this
the scale and demand of the product when it got onto the wild was just incredible and while this graph if you took out the
y axis could really represent the amount of sleep we've gotten in the past few months it really does tell a compelling
story of uh just some amazing feats of engineering some just in time engineering to stay ahead of these
issues as we scaled up to handle 100 million emails a day and that's really been the the story
for us since launch a lot of re architect on the Fly identifying pieces of the system that need to be swapped
out or improved or completely eliminated and a AWS has been a great partner in
that the flexibility and elasticity that they offer has really allowed us to move quickly and and scale this thing out and
I think if I gave you a picture of our back end a week before we launched and today the picture would be dramatically
different and I'm sure as many of you are aware when you launch a production level system you can't really know what
Productions like like until you're actually in production and um in a lot
of ways it's like jumping off a cliff and hoping everything's all right as you're on your way down and um we've
been really fortunate to be able to take advantage of uh being able to identify queuing layer uh bottlenecks identifying
parts of the system that need to be improved or optimized and we're really enjoying doing that right now we built a
lot of detailed monitoring on top of our back end that you can see here and we allows us to identify problems in the
moment and to be able to predict problems and improvements as as they're
coming and one example of this is just last week we found one of our application servers that could be
swapped out that was 16% more expensive but 72% more efficient for our use case
and we're just really enjoying going through this process and figuring out how to make our service custom fit to
our data and our usage patterns and we feel really fortunate to have AWS
partner as a partner in doing so and take to be able to take advantage of all the hard work they're doing and the new services that continue to keep coming
out so that we can focus on our product and doing what we love to do and helping
people work better together so if you haven't yet please download mailbox give
it a shot we'd love to hear what you think and thank you for having me here today [Applause]

that is very
cool so I thought I would talk a little bit about how the Enterprise is adopting AWS and this is happening at a very
rapid Pace at this point and I thought I would go back to where I left off right before Sean came
on and remind you of the benefits that we're hearing over and over again from customers and why they're moving to the
cloud and what's interesting is that there are a lot of Old Guard technology
companies that are telling Enterprises you can get all these benefits but what you need to do is do
it in the private Cloud you get to do it on premises you don't have to worry about security it may cost tens of
millions of dollars maybe over hundred million do but you'll have it on your premises
however when you actually carefully look at the benefits of why people are moving to the cloud you realize that the private cloud
has none of them and in fact for companies that are actually spending a
lot of money and time on the private Cloud it's hard to actually get even kind of core capabilities so Forester
did a analysis over the last several months of companies that have been working on private clouds and you can
see that even basic capabilities like self-service provisioning and cost charge back and resource tracking hard
to actually get done and so you ask yourself well why then are so many Old
Guard technology companies telling Enterprises that what they got to do is go build a new private cloud and I think
the reason is that the model that AWS is pursuing and that the cloud is moving to
is very disruptive to these Old Guard technology companies they have built high margin business on a set of
products that aren't quite as compelling if the world moves this direction and so it's very important as
you're thinking about as an Enterprise what you want to do to really cut through all the noise and
evaluate what value you can actually get from why so many people are moving to
the cloud now when we talk to customers about this sometimes they get really
nervous because they say well wait a second are you saying that I have to choose between two choices either all in
to AWS or all in on a private cloud and the answer is no we know that there are
a lot of Enterprises that have data center and Technology assets that they're not ready to retire yet and they
actually want to get value out of those before they transition off of them and they also want to take advantage of AWS
and the cloud and so we're building tools along with our ecosystem to make
that simple for Enterprises to do and that's why you see things like us
integrating active directory for customers with our user and identity management Services why we're building
all kinds of network configurations to make it simple to move directly from your data center to AWS and back again
it's why we're working on encryption Services it's why we're actually working on appliances that allow you to store
data in your Enterprise but asynchronously back it up to the cloud all of those types of tools are all
happening now and you'll see more of them moving forward and you'll also see us work very
closely with our ecosystem of Partners to make it simpler for Enterprises to get some of these things done so we

enough of them we watched every movie we we could and we realized that the Common Thread between all of these films was visual effects it was when the
filmmakers were using visual effects to tell a story that couldn't otherwise be told any other way and that's why we
made it our our Dream to to tell stories and to entertain people using a computer and using visual
effects and since that time we've been incredibly fortunate we've had an opportunity to work on dozens and dozens of films with amazing directors we've
also had an opportunity to work at some really amazing companies as well companies with a thousand artists that are really big and have a huge Pipeline
and you can get a ton of work done and there's a great thing about that and then there's a great thing about really small companies with just a few dozen
people uh where it's Nimble and fast and there's a great culture and Vibe um and things are a lot more efficient and so a
few years ago we had the opportunity to launch our own company and so we started Atomic fiction and it was really a combination of of these two philosophies
a big company infrastructure combined with a a small company Vibe and culture
um AWS plays a big part in that big company infrastructure and uh we bring the vibe and culture so this is a couple
of pictures of of our office uh very open and collaborative um we love for artists to be able to communicate and
yell right across the room um and see what each others see what each other are doing and hear uh calls with our
customers and really get a good sense of what's going on we also love to dress up funny every once in a while but I want
to show you guys this picture just to show you how small we really are we're only about 30 or 40 artists um at any
given time but at the same time this big Pipeline and infrastructure that we've been able to create behind Atomic
fiction is is what allows us to play with the big boys and so we're cutting up our shots against uh you know films
where where companies you know 30 times our size are working and we're having a great time and a great opportunity to do that I thought I would play our our Show
reel for you all um it's it's the best way to show you what we've been up to and a little bit of eye candy um and we usually use this to show prospective
customers or artists uh that we may want to work with and uh we'll go ahead and play that now

much so you might still be asking yourself what does this all have to do with AWS and it actually has a lot to do
with it um when we were starting our company uh we realized that it really wasn't about the technology it was about
the people people and that our artists and and the people that we work with are the most important asset and I think this is probably the case with all
companies and so we really wanted to invest in having an absolutely Rockstar team and we wanted that team to be nimble and small but we wanted them to
be the best in the world we also had to pair that with some really smart technology and and look for ways to cut
costs because at the end of the day visual effects is a very competitive industry and we want to make sure that every dollar of our client's money ends
up on the screen looking really awesome so the first thing we decided to do is that we weren't going to build this
it's amazing uh the extents people go to to make that stuff look cool um and it does look cool but at the same time it's
just a lot of expensive Hot Hardware uh that's sitting there depreciating and that you have to replace every 3 years
and for us as a visual effects company especially one that wanted to be small and Nimble we simply couldn't afford to do that um so uh what we decided to do
is uh look for other ways and and and that became AWS in the cloud so I want to tell you a little bit about rendering
also in case you guys are unfamiliar with that so rendering is really for visual effects artists like watching the paint dry
um it's when the computers chug away at the scene file that you've been working on all day and at the after a couple hours or all night it spits out an image
of what you've been working on and we all get to talk about what that work is and we get to critique each other and
and figure out what to do next so it's really important that we have all that Hardware there um and what we' like to
say with with our AWS story is that we have a Pixar size render Farm in one minute and then we're right back down to the iMac on our decks the next and
that's really critical for us from a business standpoint uh because we we basically only pay for what we use and we really treat rendering like a utility
just like gas or electricity um but there's also the side benefit which is that uh you you know as
an artist you you need to see stuff more quickly you really need to get feedback fast and you need to to understand what you need to do to make the shots look
better and and because you're paying by the proc hour you can actually just put more machines on the job and get it done
10 times faster and therefore you get more iterations throughout the day so one of the projects that we had
an amazing opportunity to work on this past year was flight and besides getting an opportunity to work with one of our filmmaking hero es uh flight was a truly
groundbreaking film for the visual effects industry um because it was the first major Studio motion picture to be entirely rendered in it in the
cloud um the other side benefit and what's really interesting about this project is that uh you know like you saw
we're a pretty small company this this film started out at around 130 shots when we were breaking down the script
and as we got into filming and we uh you know got out into production and we started editing the movie we realized that Mr zamus had increased the scope
slightly to over 400 shots and as a small company we we need to be able to move with with
the needs of our clients of course and without AWS behind us without that horsepower the seemingly unlimited
horsepower that we have uh that just wouldn't have been possible here's a typical chart of what
it looks like uh rendering over the course of a project um you have you know
these the these uh uh maybe some deadlines in the beginning you have a temp screening or a trailer Delivery
throughout the middle of the project you might have a couple of more Milestones but but then you can see the render requirements get really big at the end
of the project and I promise it's not because we procrastinate it's because there's this last 10% that goes into
shots that's really hard to do really hard to make something look real it's really easy to get 90% of the way there
and then you just spend an immense amount of time in that last that last kiss of Love is what we call it um and
that takes a lot of computing power and so um if you look at some of the stats we actually use over a million
core hours in AWS to render flight over a 6-month period which is the course of the production schedule on that show
we scaled month over month in crazy ways we used more and more horsepower and what's most astounding to me is that we
used almost half of all of the core hours in just the last 30 days alone so it really shows you um how important it
is to us and to our clients that we have that ability to really scale up and use all the horsepower we need when we're
trying to do that last 10% and make something look really perfect and real so I wanted to uh break down a shot
with you all uh just so you can kind of see what goes into it what are the types of things that we actually are rendering in the cloud this is one of the Final
Shots from flight as the aircraft is starting to tear itself apart of course in a in a nose
dive and every shot starts out pretty simple um it starts out as uh as as a
pretty simple animation pass this was done by one of our talented animators um where we really are just trying to block out the shot figure out where the camera
is working with Mr Zas on uh you know what it's going to look like as it's cut into the rest of his film and then we
might uh early in the phase render it out um so we put it up in the cloud and render this out so we can see what it
might look like a little more polished a little more finished and we we actually shot a bunch of the the footage that's
that you see back there with all the clouds on a helicopter rig um but just as an example of how even a single shot
can increase in scope um we realized that at this point in the story it felt like the air airplane wasn't enough of a
nose dive it just didn't look scary enough so we uh we we we opted to
completely create the background digitally so using satellite images and some of the photos we had taken we uh we created this background um using
Photoshop able to create some map painted Cloud elements and then another element that needs to be rendered by
someone is all these effects elements of foreground smoke that fly by the camera just to give a sense of speed and make
the shot more Dynamic and then the actual airplane itself is a really big render and this might take uh a few
hours per frame or more uh just because of all the reflections and the high detailed
textures and it just takes an immense amount of memory so we really use some of the biggest instances that Amazon can throw at it for
this and then this kiss of love that I was talking about is just a little bit of contrails just a little bit of energy
to kind of make the shot a little more interesting plus you always see this when you're flying and it looks cool so we decided to throw it in
there and you layer it all up in a final composite which again gets sent up into the cloud and what's interesting is that
because we're already rendering in the cloud all of those elements are sitting up there waiting for us so when the artist kicks off their their final composite it all comes together and uh
that's how the final shot looks so that's it for me I really
really appreciate uh appreciate your time and thank you all hope we have a wonderful week [Applause]
[Music]
here that was very cool so I'm going to close uh this talk
by answering a question that we get asked a lot and that I expect will get asked even more as more and more
technology companies are rushing to build uh something very similar to what we have built over the last seven years
and that question is how do I think about who to choose as a cloud partner there's going to be lots of noise and so
we thought we would tell you the things we think are most important as you evaluate this over time the first thing I would tell you is
that when we launched this business 7 years ago and conceived of it 10 years ago one of the reasons we did so was
that we had to get really good running deep infrastructure Services Deep In the
staff and reliable scalable cost effective data centers just to grow amazon.com the
retailer the first 10 years of Amazon and I can tell you that after 7 years of
being in the market with hundreds of thousands of customers in over 190 countries with every imaginable use case
where they use us to any degree without any warning we are much better at this today than we were 7 years ago and we
thought we were pretty good 7 years ago there's an expression we use sometimes times internally which is that there's
no compression algorithm for experience and you can't really understand some of
the things you need to adjust and change and build for until you hit certain elbows of the demand curve running these
types of services at the scale that we do so we have a lot of experience doing
this and it's not easy to accumulate those learnings until you've actually had to go through those Peaks the second thing I'd tell you is
that you're going to want to work with a cloud provider that has the broadest possible functionality the most number
of services the most number of features within those Services because it allows you to do so much more with the
workloads that you want to actually build from scratch or move to the cloud and so what you don't want to have to
settle for is an AWS Circa 2009 type of
platform as a lot of other companies are just launching their Solutions we have much broader functionality than anybody
else and we are iterating and innovating at a very fast clip you know it's motherhood
and apple pie to say you're going to listen to your customers and then deliver quickly on their behalf everybody says it but if you look in
practice at the difference in delivery pace and Innovation between AWS and
almost any other technology company in the last seven years there's a pretty stark contrast we are delivering at a
much faster clip so you get a lot lot broader functionality and you're getting
Innovation and additional capabilities at a faster Pace than anybody else is providing the fourth thing is that
you're going to want to work with a provider who's got a broad Global footprint that's going to matter you're
going to have you have Global end users and you'd like to provide a better customer experience and lower latency by
being able to serve them more locally to where they are today WS has nine regions
throughout the world and we're not done growing geographically the fifth thing i' tell
you that matters is the pricing philosophy of whoever you're working with you know almost every company I
know of cares about costs and cares about prices there are some who at any one juncture for whatever is going on in
their business cycle may not care as much about costs but eventually they will care about costs business changes
circumstances change everybody's going to care about what your cost structure is you want to be working with a partner
who has a pricing philosophy that they're going to keep lowering prices for you in a metronomic way at Amazon in
every business Amazon's in especially AWS we run high volume low margin
businesses we love those types of businesses we're very comfortable operating those businesses it's in our
DNA It Takes by the way a unique set of operating skills to be good at running
high volume low margin businesses you can't flip a switch overnight and be good at those because the scale and the
logistics of that are very different from running high margin lower volume
businesses Amazon knows how to run these types of businesses AWS consistently is
working to lower your costs and that I think is going to be important for you both now and in the future as you decide
who to build on top of long term and then the last thing I would tell you to think hard about is the
ecosystem and when you're making a technology change as substantial as this
one having partners who can help you move to the cloud in the best possible
way being able to run all the software you're used to being able to run on top
of a particular platform that partner ecosystem is a huge accelerant and makes
your life much easier and the customer ecosystem being able to know that lots
of companies in your segment or lots of companies geographically close to you
lots of your friends are using a particular platform is also very useful as you figure out how to best optimize
that platform over the long term aws's ecosystem as I talked about earlier is
really vibrant and growing really fast and already is helping so many companies
move to the cloud in a safe and successful manner so with that I'm going to thank you for coming and to thank you
for listening to the talk and I hope you enjoy the rest of the breakout sessions today and feel like it's worthwhile thanks again
